alert.note: Alert for Mora; San Miguel; Taos (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued June 30 at 9:23PM MDT until June 30 at 10:45PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING FOR THE HERMITS PEAK AND CALF CANYON BURN SCAR REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1045 PM MDT THIS EVENING FOR SOUTHEASTERN TAOS, WESTERN MORA AND NORTHWESTERN SAN MIGUEL COUNTIES... At 923 PM MDT, While showers and thunderstorms have mostly moved away from the burn scar, excessive runoff from earlier rainfall could still impact Chacon, Guadalupita and San Ignacio. Any debris flows may consist of rock, mud, ash, soot, vegetation and other loose materials. HAZARD...Earlier thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall on and around the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar. Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Mora, Ledoux, Morphy Lake State Park, Tierra Monte, Cleveland, La Cueva, Gascon, Holman, Sapello, Chacon, South Carmen, Monte Aplanado, Rociada, Manuelitas, Rainsville, Luceros, San Ignacio in Guadalupe County, Golondrinas, El Turquillo and Guadalupita. This includes the following recreation areas... El Porvenir Campground and Morphy Lake State Park. This includes the following highways... State Road 94 between Mile Markers 1 and 18. State Road 518 between Mile Markers 9 and 45. State Road 434 between Mile Markers 0 and 15. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Runoff from rainfall will cause elevated water levels within vulnerable drainages in and downstream of the Hermits Peak-Calf Canyon wildfire burn area. Do not camp along streams and rivers. Remain alert when hiking in steep, narrow canyons. Know where you are relative to low spots and drainages.
